So when we get close to the vegetation, we need 
to look for a darker spot or a black spot then

for something white. That will be the turtle. 
Do you see the white?
Oh yeah just about.

It's the dead of night and I'm hunting for sea turtles 
on a beautiful Costa Rican beach.
You can turn on your light now. Put this on? Right, OK, great. It will be easier to see her and we can get closer.

Oh, wow. What was that? She's throwing a lot of 
sand because she's camouflaging.
I'm exhausted, in complete darkness and yet I can still see the wide smile on the face of Caitlyn from the Sea Turtle Conservancy
here on Tortuguero beach, the birthplace of sea turtle conservation.
We go at night mostly, looking for tracks. So we'll find the females and we take measurements, we tag the turtles and we do

a body check for poison, health of that turtle. 
Tortuguero is one of the most important nesting

beaches in the world for green sea turtles and 
one of the reasons this animal is still here is tourism.

I grew up in Tortuguero and for us tourists are 
really important because they gave us tourism and

that is one of the main way to get money here and 
beside that they are really important like in the ecosystem.

This is The Climate Question from the 
BBC World Service. I'm Qasa Alom and this week I'm

on a journey in Costa Rica, the home of ecotourism, 
to ask: Can tourism ever really be good for the environment?

We keep working until the 
sun rises. I realise the sand between my toes

is black. It's sticky and humid already and beyond 
the roaring waves I can see a huge storm brewing

over the Caribbean. It's magnificent. For now 
Caitlyn and I are the only people here but

soon this place will be packed with visitors 
coming here to help protect Costa Rica's famous

green sea turtles. We receive eco-volunteers. And 
what work do they actually do to help?
They can take measurements and they can help us counting the eggs while the turtle is laying. So they

help us with the money of course but we give 
them like the experience. Most of them really

love it because it's something completely 
different and they get involved in the work

we do here. And that's important isn't it, making 
sure that people are involved and then they care

about the animals, care about the environment? 
Yeah, when people get involved in nature they

understand more the importance of that. It's a 
far cry from how things used to be. In the 1960s,

it wasn't tourists but poachers on the lookout 
for sea turtles leaving them on the brink of extinction.

Thankfully though, since Costa Rica 
banned sea turtle and egg consumption at Tortuguero,

as well as a government decision to become an 
ecotourism hotspot, both the turtle numbers and

tourism have flourished. When the national parks 
began in the 1970s, we started to have an increase

of the population of green sea turtles and that 
was good, so everybody was happy.
But recently numbers are back on the slide to the lowest recorded in 25 years and Caitlyn believes this

could be down to climate change. The sea level 
rise can be negative in the nesting beaches.

Also the erosion is negative because the nest will 
be destroyed and the beach will get smaller and

smaller so they will not have enough place to 
go and lay their eggs. The temperature is higher

because of the climate change. We have really 
low percentage of hatching success because of
the temperature. The hatchlings don't develop. How sad is that, that's so bad isn't it? I want to ask you

a little bit about tourism. We've talked about 
how important tourism has been for Costa Rica

for the people even actually their money to 
help the numbers of turtles flourish as well

but equally when we have so many tourists flying 
over here adding to the carbon in the atmosphere

which is leading to global warming I mean that 
could also be harming the turtles in the long

run by making the climate warmer as well. What do 
you think about that? Yeah that is a interesting

question. I didn't think about that before
but it's true that a lot of tourists flying

here can contribute to the climate change and yeah 
affect sea turtles in the future and now, so it's like

a 50/50, tourists help us being here helping us 
protecting sea turtles but they also can have negative consequences.

Ecotourism is the buzz in tourism 
right now. It was worth $92 billion globally in

2019 and it's forecasted to generate $103 billion 
by 2027. I've travelled to one of the shining

beacons of eco-tourism for the BBC's Travel Show 
but while here I wanted to help my friends at The

Climate Question to weigh up how much good 
it actually does versus the impact on the

climate but first I need to understand, what does 
eco-tourism actually mean? I think I know exactly

the right person to help figure that out: Ralph 
Buckley, a professor at Griffith University in Australia and a man who has literally written the book on it.
When the idea of eco-tourism was first put forward, which was in the 1970s, the idea was that tourism could be an economic engine that

would fund conservation and local communities 
and that it could be managed to minimise its

environmental impacts and it could create a 
contribution to conservation.
Effectively that means get lots of rich Western tourists to come to beautiful countries and use their cash to conserve

and protect the wildlife. Sounds simple enough but 
not really.

Since that time it's never been very well defined. To complicate matters further lots of 
other terms have also come into the equation like

sustainable tourism, responsible tourism and even 
regenerative tourism.
People used to talk about sustainable tourism and again this was the idea that it would have an economic contribution to

local communities and it would contribute to the 
environment. The idea of responsible tourism is
that there were going to be opportunities for the individual tourists to take actions to benefit the
environment but again super vague you know concept. When people get to see that one particular term

doesn't mean very much they invent another one, so 
the idea of regenerative tourism is that tourists

will somehow contribute to the regeneration of 
the host communities that they visit.
Personally I think that all these different terms don't really mean very much, you know. Unless they're incorporated

in legislation then what matters is not what it's 
called but what people actually do.
So say there is a tour operator or a company that is falsely labelling itself as sustainable or regenerative

and actually not doing anything of the case, what 
sort of penalties would there be in place for them?

At the moment I'd say that there aren't 
any. There are two possible options - so there is

a government legislation regulation option, for 
example if you are tour operator and you want

to take people into a national park you have to 
have a permit and that permit can be withdrawn because

then you can't operate your tours you can't make any 
money. That doesn't happen very often. Even though

conditions are breached usually there's only a 
wrap on the knuckles. And then there are obviously

market-based measures, such as certification. The 
problem is that they're not regulated, so anybody

can set up a competing certification program 
where you can pay a lot of money to have a

green tick from Mr X but from us, Mrs Y, or whoever 
you can have the same or very similar green tick

for a rather smaller amount of money. So you get 
these multiple competing systems. So all of these
certification programs don't really work.

That's quite damning on the pitfalls of ecotourism from one of the world's leading experts in it. At the 
moment there's no real consistency - it's the wild

west - an unregulated space full of tall tales and 
bold claims. But Costa Rica is the poster child
of ecotourism. How well is it really working there?

So I've made it to Corcovado National Park, which is one of the most biodiverse places on the planet and 
there's a gentle little stream on my left. We've

got banana trees and there's a beautiful glow 
from the morning light coming down and making

everything look absolutely spectacular. We're 
going to go out on a patrol today where we're

going to try and keep the place protected 
from poachers, miners and loggers. This whole

area has been part of a fierce intense battle 
between those who want to protect the animals

and keep this place safe for tourists and those 
who want to survive and we're just about to head out.

Corcovado National Park is in the Osa 
Peninsula on the South Pacific Coast of the

country. It's a place teaming with wildlife 
that attracts thousands of tourists each

year. There are 400 species of birds and 5% of 
the planet's animal population crammed into

this rainforest but equally there are 
plenty of precious resources here too

like gold and timber. I'm told to stay close to 
Alejandro, a small ranger with ferocious green eyes.

We all have weapons because we have 
sometimes had very serious difficulties

with people, more than anything with 
hunters, not miners, but hunters can

be the ones who get defensive. 
Have you ever feared for your life?

Several times, both me 
and my colleagues have had

problems where we've practically felt 
that it will be the last day of our life.

Costa Rica is indeed a green country, 
it's preached all over the world that it

is a green country. We love nature but there 
are many people who are still unaware that

it shouldn't be harmed. The Osa Peninsula 
practically lives off tourism because there

are jaguars but people are still hunting, 
they are killing the animals that attract

tourists. Right now we have a very big problem 
that the government is not prioritising these
forests and they are not hiring park rangers. We are only 20 park rangers for a big forest,

almost 47,000 hectares. That works out to each of 
these rangers needing to be across about 6,000

football pitches worth of land, staggering when you 
think about it. But the scale of this forest does

show the success of Costa Rica's eco-tourism 
model. The country's forest cover has doubled

from a quarter in 1983 to more than half in 2021 
thanks to the government's decision to create more

protected areas. And of course that forest helps 
to suck planet warming carbon dioxide out of the

air and although there aren't enough rangers to 
help Alejandro keep across the land, some studies

suggest the increase in tourism numbers acts as 
a human deterrent keeping hunters away. During the

pandemic when tourism stopped hunting, mining 
and logging reached levels not seen here for years.

I do believe tourism is very important 
if you know how to benefit the communities. Many

people will stop mining and dedicate themselves 
to tourism if they get some benefits. It's a way

of indirectly helping conservation. Through my 
knowledge of the forest I abandoned mining forever.

I had no idea that Alejandro himself had been 
a gold miner for more than 20 years but partly

due to tourism he's gone from harming nature to 
protecting it. But of course there's an elephant

in the room or more accurately in the sky. Although 
tourists may have helped Costa Rica to conserve some

of its wildlife, the way visitors get there is 
a huge issue. We have calculated that tourism's

contribution to global warming in 2019 is about 
10% of the overall total.
Stefan Gossling is from Lund University in Sweden. He researches tourism, transport and sustainability.
Aviation is about one-third of overall total emissions from tourism. Another third is from food and the last third is

then different transport modes but also 
accommodation and perhaps the shopping and
activities that you do in the destination.
That is staggering listening to you say 10% of global CO2 emissions comes from tourism.
Well I might reveal as much as saying that when the new calculations are going to be published then we are looking into a higher figure, considerably higher.

Sobering stuff, especially since we need to 
half our emissions over the next decade in order

to meet our climate targets. And it's not 
just the flying that's an issue here. As Stefan

says other aspects of tourism are also bad for 
the planet. Then you have accommodation and that

very much depends on the type of accommodation 
that you're choosing, if you are going to stay

in a five-star hotel you might have a very 
significant carbon footprint but then if you

go to a middle class hotel or even a campsite 
perhaps, these emissions will be very small.

What is it about the accommodation, is it the electric 
bills, is it the food?
Accommodation is mostly heating and cooling, you have to imagine in many tropical destinations we have ACs running,

they are very electricity-consuming and that 
then depends on how the electricity is generated

or sourced. Food is a surprisingly large carbon 
footprint. The type of food consumed in tourism

is often more carbon intense because it's high in 
protein, more meat, more fish, more seafood.

For this programme Stefan we're visiting Costa Rica. 
It's seen as a real global example of using

tourism responsibly. I'm curious to know what you 
make of that statement?
I definitely believe that Costa Rica is a country that has managed to make a lot out of its tourism system also because

tourism has been supportive of growth that has 
been more small scale involving local businesses,

local workforces and that has helped to make 
Costa Rica a very stable country, probably the
most stable country in all of Central America.

In 2021, Costa Rica earned nearly 5% of its GDP from tourism and that is clear to see. From restaurants, 
roads and hotels, as well as smaller businesses,

there are signs of bigger developments everywhere 
and not everyone is happy about this. Back in the

Osa Peninsula I'm going for a drive with Gabs, 
an adventure tour operator. We're winding up a

steep mountain on the edge of the rainforest 
that's making my stomach turn in knots.

I saw a puma here right up this road, it's kind of 
amazing, just crossing the road.
Just crossing the road, how casual. I've been wanting to see it. And what does it look like then? It's a pretty

big intimidating cat, I'll tell you that much. Were 
you scared? I was pretty far from it so no I was

actually just more in awe. I was really excited 
to be able to witness that, it was beautiful.

The thing is I wouldn't have known this was a puma's 
territory without Gabs pointing it out.
You see on one side the area is lush, green, full of trees but on the other there's scaffolding and workmen.

It's noisy. They've been clearing out these areas, 
which I guess, you know, I'm worried about the puma's territory of course.
The construction around us is to build more than 90 luxury
homes for tourists and Gabs says there are more and more areas like this popping up all the time.

Costa Rica's infrastructure, natural beauty, as well as 
the political and economic stability has helped

cement its reputation as one of the places to 
visit in the world and that's shown in the visitor

numbers as well. In the last two decades tourist 
numbers have shot up by 320%.
It's been just going faster and faster, you know, because I could tell you for sure that 10 years ago this didn't look

like this. It's also like one thing that will make 
wildlife leave. Last time I got off I could see

that they expanded this road, you see the dirt on 
the sides and so the puma is going to feel

like their terrain was completely you know it's sent,
it's gone, so we probably will never see it here again.

Although earlier I mentioned that Costa 
Rica's forest cover is doubled, only around a quarter of the land is certified as in protected areas,
meaning the country is ripe for development away from national parks.
Marie, another tour operator further up the coast, says sometimes
even protection isn't enough.
Especially right now we are in a huge, huge I would say battle in the Caribbean side because the local government is allowing some foreign people to chop a huge portion

of the forest to build hotels in the coastal 
line and that place used to be protected.
They just changed the law but why, you know? We already have a lot of hotels there and you know what we don't need need more.
I get the sense from some Costa Ricans that the country is in danger

of becoming a victim of its own success. It's 
become so well equipped at being an eco-tourist

destination that the very reason people choose 
to come here - the rainforests, the animals and

the untouched beauty - is being compromised in 
order to accommodate the influx of tourists.
We put these claims to the Environment Minister from the Costa Rican government but we didn't receive a response.
My final stop on this incredible journey across Costa Rica has me whistling after a bird called Suzie.
It's a nickname of the streak-chested antpitta that lives

in this pristine forest and a favourite 
of my guide 19-year-old Samantha.
It's my favourite because when I call the pitta come and maybe it's 2 metres, 4 metres close to me. No way.
Yeah, it's not the same like the other birds, it's totally different.

You are so good at that. Thank you. It's 
many years practice.
Inspired by Samantha, I thought I'd have a go myself but rather than attract any birds I brought about a deluge of rain.

Samantha and I took refuge under a roof 
where I watched the rain fall on the leaves

with a feeling of calm and contentment. I wondered 
if other tourists have had a sense of awakening

to the natural world after visiting her country. 
You clearly have a lot of tourists come here do

the bird trails, spot birds like me. When they leave 
what's their emotion, what are they like?

I see the people look excited. A new place, this 
ecosystem with the birds, plants, I think
when they go they are connected with that natural place.

You hear this a lot, this notion that tourism has an intangible benefit to the world that science 
can't quantify. That when a person travels it can

awaken something within to change their behaviour. 
I put this idea to Ralph Buckley from Griffith

University, who we heard from at the beginning of 
the programme.
Yes that can happen but you have to say well OK so that one person is in a group of 50 what happens with the other 49 and does that

one person actually do anything about it and if so 
does what they do about it outweigh the impacts of

the other 49? There has actually been quite a bit 
of research where researchers have gone on tours

with people to very eco-oriented destinations 
like the Antarctic for example and said

now that you've seen the wonder of nature are 
you going to change your life so as to do more

to support conservation and they're like "No, we're 
on holiday".
OK perhaps not and unfortunately while the idea that these small ripples can lead to waves of change is nice, for Ralph the
reality is it won't be enough.

We very much have the situation where tourism does have positive impacts as you've said for local communities in 
many developing countries and it can, not always

but it can, have positive impacts for conservation 
but the cost is its contribution to climate change

and there isn't really any way to avoid that 
unpleasant part of the equation.
So what you're saying Ralph is that individually on a local level there can actually be some environmental

positives from eco-tourism but on a global level 
it's doing more harm than good?
Yes I think that regrettably that is indeed the case and it's not that anyone's doing it intentionally it's just

that aircraft travel creates contributions to 
climate change that we have not yet worked out

how to overcome. I don't think that we're going 
to see any substantial reductions in tourism in
the short term.
The solution for Stefan Gossling from Lund University is to drastically alter our behaviour. He's only taken one flight in the last five years and says we need to majorly rethink how
we price flights.
The most important part is probably to internalise the cost of carbon dioxide and the price of travel and that would help everyone to make an assessment

as to whether you would really travel 
just for two weeks or rather three weeks and

then do one trip less, perhaps where possible 
use a different mode of transportation and so on.

That would then help to also generate 
funds that can be used to restructure in

the global aviation industry, for instance where 
we need new fuels, new technology all at a huge cost.

I've travelled all around Costa Rica and 
seen some amazing sights. The way the country does

eco-tourism is a model for the rest of the world 
to follow but it's not perfect. Yes locally it's

supporting businesses, livelihoods and even 
health the wildlife around here to flourish

but on a global level it's a different story. 
I'm mindful that every person who takes part

in eco-tourism, including myself, creates a carbon 
cost that the rest of the planet has to take.

That's it from us this week, thanks for 
listening. What are your thoughts on eco-tourism?

Email us at theclimatequestion@bbc.com. We love 
to hear from you. This programme was researched by
Octavia Woodward. The producers were Sophie Eastaugh and Jamie Hamilton. Series producer is Simon Watts.

Editor China Collins and the man behind the mix
is Tom Brignell. I'm Qasa Alom. Goodbye.
